010package imagingbook.common.noise.hashing;
011
012/**
013 * <p>
014 * Hash function proposed by G Ward in [1]. See [2] for details.
015 * </p>
016 * <p>
017 * [1] G. Ward, "A recursive implementation of the Perlin noise function",
018 * Graphics Gems II (1991).<br>
019 * [2] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Principles of Digital Image Processing &ndash;
020 * Advanced Methods</em> (Vol. 3), Supplementary Chapter 8: "Synthetic Gradient
021 * Noise", Springer (2013).
022 * </p>
023 * 
024 * @author WB
025 * @version 2022/11/24
026 */
027public class Hash32Ward extends Hash32 {
028        
029        /**
030         * Constructor, creates a hash function with a random seed value.
031         */
032        public Hash32Ward() {
033                this(0);
034        }
035        
036        /**
037         * Constructor creating a hash function with the specified seed value.
038         * @param seed the random seed value (set to 0 use a random seed value).
039         */
040        public Hash32Ward(int seed) {
041                super(seed);
042        }
043        
044        @Override
045        int hashInt(int key) {
046                key = key + seed;       // WB added
047                // lower 16 bits are highly repetitive and "perfectly" uniform!
048                key = (key << 13) ^ key; // ^ denotes bitwise XOR operation
049                key = (key * (key * key * 15731 + 789221) + 1376312589);
050                return key;
051        }
052        
053        public static void main(String[] args) {
054                Hash32Ward hf = new Hash32Ward();
055                for (int k = 0; k < 256; k++) {
056                        System.out.format("%d : %10f\n", k, hf.hash(k));
057                        
058                }
059        }
060}
